did.head: Papers Summary
did.unittitle: Rufus W. Weaver papers
did.abstract: This collection contains materials produced by Dr. Rufus W. Weaver, a noted Southern Baptist pastor, educator, and cultural commentator. Weaver was the president of Mercer University, and his later church-state work led directly to the founding of the Baptist Joint Committee on Public Affairs.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Rufus Washington Weaver was born in Greensboro, North Carolina, on 1870 June 3. As a young man, Weaver worked as a printer and a journalist. Weaver received an A.B. and M.A. from Wake Forest College in 1893, a Th.D. from Southern Baptist Seminary in 1899, and four additional degrees between 1912 and 1920. He married Charlotte Mason Payne in 1911.

All the while, Weaver was both pastoring Baptist churchesDLfrom North Carolina to Ohio to MarylandDLand beginning a longstanding involvement in Baptist education. Weaver started by teaching high school, moved on to leadership of the Baptist Education Board in Tennessee, and eventually became the president of Georgia’s Mercer University, a position he held from 1918 to 1927. During and after his time at Mercer, Weaver remained active in the educational work of the Southern Baptist Convention, and in his later years he instructed graduate students at the American University in Washington, DC.

After he left Mercer University, most of Weaver’s professional work took place in the nation’s capital and centered on the relationship of church and state. A prolific author, Weaver published numerous books and pamphlets on the relationship of Christianity to American culture, including a collection of sermons titled The Christian Faith at the Nation’s Capital (1936). Weaver also had key leadership roles in the District of Columbia Baptist Convention and the Southern Baptist Committee on Public Relations. The latter organizationDLtogether with similar committees from the Northern Baptist Convention and the National Baptist Convention USA, Inc.DLwas later subsumed into the Baptist Joint Committee on Public Affairs, which in turn maintained and then donated Weaver's personal papers to Baylor University. Rufus W. Weaver died in Washington, DC, on 1947 January 31.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of written and printed materials produced by Rufus W. Weaver between 1906 and 1947. Most of these materials are formal documentsDLtexts prepared for publication or oral deliveryDLand most relate to Weaver’s ongoing engagement with Southern Baptist education and public policy. The first and third series are roughly equal in size, and together take up the vast majority of the collection. The materials are in average condition.

The first series, Series I. “An Introduction to Christianity” Manuscript, contains tables of contents and chapter drafts for an unpublished manuscript which Weaver seems to have begun in the late 1920s and continued writing into the 1940s. Though the exact scope and purpose of this work remain uncertain, the manuscript seems to provide a systematic overview of world history, world religions, and the history and philosophy of Christianity more specifically. There are multiple iterations of most chapter drafts, often with multiple titles or numbering systems, and these variants are indicated in the folder titles.

The second series, Series II. Mercer University, contains the texts of addresses, statements, and articles written by Weaver during his time as the president of Mercer University (1918-1927). A large number of these documents are historical sketches meant to communicate the importance of Mercer University to Georgia Baptists and to Southern Baptists more broadly.

The final series, Series III. Christianity and Culture, contains the remainder of Weaver’s literary productions, including addresses, lectures, notes, pamphlets, and sermons. The contents of this series are more varied than those of the previous two, but nearly all revolve around the relationship of the Baptist faith to American culture. Many of the documents in this series lack titles and dates, and several are incomplete.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Prior to current processing, this collection was arranged in titled folders which were grouped into five series: “An Introduction to Christianity” Manuscript, Mercer University Items, Church-State Materials, Baptists Papers, and Miscellaneous Items. An initial inventory, found within the collection, suggests that the materials arrived in no particular order and were then arranged into these five groups through an earlier round of processing.

To preserve any remaining original order, the latest processing has made minimal modifications to the collection’s preexisting organization. At a basic level, the materials have been refoldered and retitled for more specificity. Additionally, the first two seriesDLSeries I. “An Introduction to Christianity” Manuscript and Series II. Mercer UniversityDLhave been adopted, while the third through fifth series have been combined into one series, Christianity and Culture.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Described by Ben Leavitt. Released on 2017-10-11.

Archivist''s Notes: Weaver’s book manuscript seems to have been edited and updated frequently. An article in the folder “Biographical Items on Rufus W. Weaver” indicates that, by 1939, Weaver had written 500,000 words of an “as yet unfinished manuscript.” The chapter drafts in this collection, most of them unpublished, presumably made up that enormous work. Due to Weaver’s constant revision and renumbering of chapters, however, the exact scope and purpose of his book remain uncertain. Among other things, Weaver appears to have drafted his magnum opus in smaller parts, cobbled them together, and then repurposed some parts for other settings. For instance, some chapters originally intended for this manuscript seem to have made their way into Weaver’s The Revolt Against God: The Conflict Between Culture and Christianity (1944). As such, the materials in Series I may simultaneously comprise one large manuscript and several smaller works, and even the title of the former is uncertain. “An Introduction to Christianity” is a well-educated guess based on information available within the collection.

As a final note, the previous organization of this collection left behind a number of loose papers, single pages of notes and manuscripts grouped into a final “Miscellaneous Papers” folder. These materials are unorganized and still located in the last folder, but may provide helpful context for other portions of the collection.

relatedmaterial.head: Related collection materials
relatedmaterial.archref: Weaver’s personal papers should be consulted in conjunction with two other sources: his executive director series within the Baptist Joint Committee records (Accession #3193, The Texas Collection, Baylor University) and his papers located at the Southern Baptist Historical Library and Archives (#AR 99).

did.unittitle: "An Introduction to Christianity" Manuscript

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This series contains a book manuscriptDLincluding tables of contents, chapter drafts, and bibliographiesDLwritten by Rufus W. Weaver between the 1920s and the 1940s. The book appears to be an overarching summary of religion’s historic role in culture, with a particular focus upon Christianity. This series is in average condition.

Mercer University

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This series includes addresses, articles, statements, and other documents produced by Rufus Weaver while he was the president of Georgia’s Mercer University (1918-1927). Many of these documents relate to Mercer’s role in establishing Baptist churches, colleges, and seminaries across the South. The series is in average condition.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This series is comprised of the lecture and research notes, addresses, statements, and sermons of Rufus W. Weaver. Most of these materials were produced during Weaver’s later years, while he was living in Washington, but some relate to his early pastoral ministry. This series is in average condition.
